subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] New to the Quikscript
msgSnippet: Hi Ryan, You should start by reading both Read s and any other manuals that are on the groups web site. That and check out a number of the message threads on
messageBody:
Hi Ryan,

You should start by reading both Read's and any other manuals that are on the groups web site. That and check out a number of the message threads on the group.

I've tried to not get too hung up on the whole dialect thing. Since this is a phonitic system, I spell it as a say it. If I was speaking to you, you'd most likely understand me, and most likely once you've been using Quickscript for a while, you'd understand my writing. You might even get a chuckle or a laugh at my dialect coming out in it.

Good luck, ohh... one more hint. Its helped me a lot to read as much of it as possibe. What ever you write, go back and re-read it a few days later. The learning of whole word form/shape is very important to reading it with speed.

Again, good luck.

 tribal_misfit <tribal_misfit@...> wrote:

     Hello everyone.  :)  I'm a new to the board; I just discovered
the Read Alphabet the other day on Omniglot.com and I was fascinated
by the idea of using a different script to write English.  I've got
most of the letters down (at least in its "junior" form), but there
are some letters that I'm not sure how to use, and some sounds for
which I'm not sure which letter to use, for instance the common "er"
suffix, as in "maker". 
     Also, I was wondering how users of the alphabet deal with
different pronounciations due to differences in dialect.  Is there
a "standard" Read form for each English word, or would one simply
write the words as his or her dialect pronounces them?
     If these questions have been answered anywhere else on board,
could someone direct me to the thread they're in?  Thanks.

Ryan

I've tried to not get too hung up on the whole dialect thing. Since this is a phonitic system, I spell it as a say it. If I was speaking to you, you'd most likely understand me, and most likely once you've been using Quickscript for a while, you'd understand my writing. Good luck, ohh... one more hint. Its helped me a lot to read as much of it as possibe. What ever you write, go back and re-read it a few days later. The learning of whole word form/shape is very important to reading it with speed.
Again, good luck.
